questions.text: Uranium is the heaviest element with a one-letter atomic symbol, U.
questions.explanation:
True.

	The others are hydrogen (H), boron (B), carbon (C), nitrogen (N), oxygen (O), fluorine (F), phosphorus (P), sulfur (S), potassium (K), vanadium (V), yttrium (Y), iodine (I), and tungsten (W).

questions.text: Uranium was first isolated as an element in:
questions.explanation:
1841.

	By Peligot, who reduced the anhydrous chloride with potassium.

questions.text: Uranium was used in the two atomic bombs dropped on Japan in WWII; one bomb used it as the main explosive, the other as a tamper around a plutonium core. On which city was the strictly-uranium bomb dropped?
questions.explanation:
Hiroshima.

	The 'Little Boy' bomb is known as a gun-barrel-type atomic bomb. It is estimated that less than 1 kilogram of uranium-235 fissioned, producing an explosion equivalent of 15 to 20 kilotons of TNT. Plutonium was the core material used in the 'Fat Man' bomb dropped on Nagasaki.  It's core was surrounded by uranium which acted as a tamper.
